comments.commentBody: No matter what Republican pundits say about Trump, and no matter what vile things he says, his supporters won’t see him for the super-sized con man he is. Now they even seem willing to forgive him when he says, sorry I’m not really the man you’ve been cheering. It all reeks of the same loyalty shown by a physically abused mate who rationalizes that the abuser is really a good person who cares about them. So if nothing can convince Trump supporters to open their eyes, then can he do anything as a president that might change their tune? Suppose he issued an executive order to round up Moslems and put them in internment camps? Suppose he called on the military to transport 11 million people south of the border, dropping them off in the desert to make their way home. Would they criticize him then? What will they say when his trade barriers bring down the economy? Or suppose all those white supremacist groups that love him so much (they understand his real appeal) felt emboldened enough to grow their numbers and start exerting their influence in ways that put all minorities in jeopardy? At what point do his supporters realize the America he has made great again no longer holds any of the values that makes America great. The fact is they won’t. They will love him even more. This is the scariest thing of all. They won’t be any better off, but most of them (the white ones at least) will feel their role has shifted from being abused to being the abuser. How great is that?

Pygmalion?  Try PIGmalion.  If Mr. Higgins thinks he's going to mold Trump into someone presentable, it's just lipstick on a pig, as they say.  And in the case of the sexist, misogynistic Mr. Trump, he's an insult to actual pigs.
Trump has played both the ventriloquist and the ventriloquist's dummy for so long that to know which may be which is a challenge for anyone, including the candidate himself, to say.

There is a definite possibility that Donald Trump will be the next President of the United States.  I find it interesting that his campaign is saying things like "He isn't really going to deport 11 million illegals"  or "He isn't really going to stop Muslim immigration".  His supporters are counting on him doing exactly that, so I wonder if they will feel betrayed?  The man care solely about how much attention gets paid to him and little else.  If we elect Trump as our next President, we deserve what we get.

So his next move is to tell all those people who became infatuated with the undisciplined Donald Trump, "Don't worry, suckers, that was all just an act."  If this works, it only confirms that P.T. Barnum was right.

If Trump really planned to change, he could begin by apologizing to those he's insulted so far in this election, starting with women in general and Megyn Kelly in particular. He could take responsibility for inciting the mobs at his rallies to violence, and apologize to the protesters that have been beaten at those events. He could admit that his comments regarding Mexico and the Mexican people were lies and distortions. He could apologize to the millions of law-abiding Muslims living in the US that have been hurt and stigmatized by his threats.

Of course, none of those things will happen, and Mr. Manafort will not be successful. Manafort's mandate, to create the New and Improved Trump, are no more than putting lipstick on a pig. Nothing can turn Trump into a presidential candidate that anyone can look up to, admire or respect. He will be the same embarrassing spectacle, just mouthing someone else's thoughts and ideas.

It has been said that the greatest threat to civilization is climate change, which means the greatest threat to civilization is the Republican Party. Well, that, in turn, means the greatest threat to civilization are the those who vote Republican.

Say whatever you want about Donald Trump, but I am deeply appreciative of him for showing us two things. First, he does not stop to consider the popularity of his points of view before offering them. When most of the rest of the Republican party is happy to make it difficult for transgender people to use a public bathroom in the south, Trump demonstrates he's not a "true Republican" by saying that everyone should decide for themselves what is the appropriate bathroom to use. No hidden agenda!!! And second, by using a megaphone instead of a dog whistle, he has shown the world how at least one third of the Republican party is crass, bigoted, deeply racist, unabashedly ignorant, mean and just plain angry.

If the Republicans want to be an effective, vital political party, they have to change. Instead of wasting $trillions when in power and grinding government to a halt when Democrats are, they need to demonstrate effective leadership by working with Democrats to achieve the best possible outcome for all Americans. That means they can no long take the people they don't like and find ways to keep them from voting like throwing them in jail.

If instead they do nothing, then someone like Trump will come and fill the void.

So you're chastising the New York Times for being brave enough and honest enough to call out Trump on his xenophobia, sexism, misogyny, anti-intellectualism, complete ignorance of foreign and domestic policy, mendacity, boorishness, rudeness, pettiness, etc. -- all fatal flaws that have been captured clearly and perfectly on video after video, thereby negating his and his team's ability to deny it all down the road?

I look forward to Trump's coronation as the Republican nominee, followed by his overwhelming rejection by voters who are intelligent enough to believe what they've been seeing and hearing for months from/about the Bilious Billionaire, followed by the disintegration of the GOP.

We've had "The square Deal," "The New Deal," and "The Fair Deal" and now the master of "The Art of the Deal" is giving us "The Re-Deal."  But the question the voters will be asking is: Is it "The Real Deal" or "The Raw Deal"?

"Intellectual laziness". This describes Mr. Trump in a nutshell. I can see it now. The morning newspapers at President Trump's Whitehouse will be NY Post, and the National Enquirer. The weekly news periodical will be People Magazine.

There seems to be a not-so-subtle implication that Trump, who has epitomized "intellectual laziness" and continually spewed self-reassuring drivel throughout his campaign, isn't smart enough to be President. Sure, he isn't the strongest on foreign policy, nor is he capable enough to lay out the specifics for any of his questionable plans regarding immigration, military, or anything for that matter.

But he certainly is smart enough to con the majority of voters into voting fo him. His aura of authenticity is unrivalled; Cruz pales in comparison to him in that respect. And maybe that's what voters want. They want a guy who can promise them the utopia they have longed for. They yearn for an outsider who thinks he knows what he's doing when he employs insults and derogatory statements to make his point. He's playing the game on his own terms, and he knows exactly what he's doing. His ego also needs to be satiated -- and he's found just the right avenue to do so.

To compare Trump with a pretentious and petulant child would, at this point, be an insult to pretentious and petulant children.

Pygmalion? Hardly!

The only thing Trump actually had going for him was his brash persona, a strong claim to politically incorrect audacity, and a crude brand of authenticity.

The notion of a makeover suggests something akin to a bazaar amalgamation of the Three Stooges.

Seventeen started and three remain; the Republican field has been farcical from the get go. Disgraceful and embarrassing beyond the pale.

It is very difficult to cover up bright paint with one coat of white.

Trump has sold himself as a bad-mouthing, overbearing thug and his appeal is documented by the large number of followers. What in the world can Mr. Manafort do to soften the image and still retain the followers?

Trump has struck me as strictly a "What you see is what you get" candidate and sadly one that is without leadership knowledge of presidential requirements.

Reagan was an awful President. OK, he resisted starting any major wars, despite the nuclear-trigger-happy faux cowboy persona. But Beyond that?

He ran racist campaigns, left the biggest deficits in history (at that time, topped by the Bush family), ballooned the national debt (70% of it is due to him and the Georges Bush), destroyed organised labour (working class wages have been stagnant since), rolled back pollution regulations (with an Interior Secretary who thought we didn't need to worry about the environment because Jesus was coming soon), put one of the worst Justices in history on the Supreme Court, openly courted religious extremists, was blatantly homophobic and ignored the existence HIV/AIDS while tens of thousands of people were dying, etc.

That he is lionised by anyone is a sad indictment of America.

Trump is woefully unqualified for the office. (He is also far from the business genius he claims to be -- there's pretty good evidence he would have been wealthier today if he'd put his very large inheritance in an index fund and just let it grow.)

But given the alternatives on that side of the aisle -- Cruz, who seems to be a full-on sociopath and Kasich who is Reagan-esque in hiding his inner viciousness behind a practised genial front -- I'd just as soon have Trump as the GOP nominee, as I figure he is the least likely to win. One can only hope this election creates the long-overdue GOP implosion that might restore some sanity to its future.

Lincoln weeps.

His "skill set" turned $1 million into billions, but that's not enough to run a country?  Riiiight.  If Trump accomplishes only a fraction of what he promises, he will have done more for this country than the eight years preceding him.  As for being elected local alderman, you don't produce four well-grounded well-spoken adult children unless you've got something solid in your heart.   As for being a polished statesman, well, we have one of those, too, and that hasn't done the country much good.  I'm ready for a bare-knuckled hardscrabbler.  As Trump says, we've lost our spirit, and if it takes a reality star to restore it, I'm for it.  Personally, I'm up to here with professional politicians who come into office with $ and leave with $$$$$.  I say let someone who can balance a checkbook and pinch a penny give it a go.  He personally knows this country's untapped talent who will apply their considerable acumen to our fragile economy.  I think he's patriotic enough that he'll pour his heart and soul into the job, not pay golf half the time.  "Trophy trinket."  Pfffft!  This country would be lucky to be one of Trump's trinkets.

One things the GOP has never learned is that you cannot put lipstick on a pig and convince a majority of voters that the result is not just a pig with lipstick on it. Henry Higgin’s Alisa Doolittle wanted to learn, wanted to change and the result was a success. Donald Trump knows better and cannot be taught. At rock solid foundation Mr. Trump is a con-artist, a fraudster whose success came from being born rich, always lived rich and began business on his own with money that his father gave him. Trump businesses have gone into bankruptcy and some like Trump University are outright predaory theft promising something never delivered.

He has a large following because he has tapped into anger with politicians and he sold himself as a non-politician and now the plan is surprise I am a real politician and know enough about the workings of government to be president.

No matter what Trump does he cannot survive a debate on the issues with Hillary Clinton as anyone who saw her town hall meeting on MSNBC would know. What Trump need is knowledge, not a new political coach, he would need a brain transplant from Ted Cruz, which is not a bad idea. He has plenty to spare if little else.

Leading and cheerleading are two entirely different things. Waving a flag and chanting "We're number one" accomplishes nothing other than giving people a false and superficial high. To the extent that anyone buys into it, they are as shallow as the candidates they worship.

By virtue of his campaign slogan, Mr. Trump acknowledges that America is no longer great. In order to be great again, we'll need a truly great and inspiring leader. Anyone who thinks Donald Trump is that person is delusional.

The recent utterances of Trump, including imitating an Indian at the call centre, does not behove of a future president of the United States. I have been carefully following the speeches of Trump. Most of his speeches made by him on foreign policy, the state of the economy, has expsoed his lack of understanding and depth on complex issues.He seems to be completely out of depth while articulating on critical issues.

It is said a country gets a leader it deserves. I honestly prey that the people of the United States are saved of blushes, for they deserve a much better leader than Trump. Although, there has been a lot of strident criticism on Hillary Clinton's integrity, but one has to admit that, when it comes intellectual prowess, she is streets ahead of Trump

I have voted democratic for the last 40 years. I now hope trump not only gets the nod but wins the election. Why? Because he is the non politician. This country has devolved into a series of special interests camps. With money as literally the coin of the realm. We need something or someone who can change the dynamics. The other three candidates, Clinton sanders Cruz, will only bring more of the same. Stasis. Deadlock. Special interests.  I really don't care if they impeach trump after Six months on the job. Something new, something different needs to be tried here. The United States of America is very far from United. We only have ourselves to blame.

I feel as if I am living in an alternate universe.....down is up and black is white. This real estate investor has shown himself to be a liar, a racist, uninformed and a chauvinist and yet his supporters say he "tells it like it is". If what he says is truth then I don't like this universe, especially as a female. How can he be shown over and over to be lying and yet he "tells it like it is"? How can his absurd proposals, which are completely unworkable, be considered as something plausible?

And then there is Clinton, who's statements are rated by the fact checkers as true or mostly true, and yet she is constantly called a liar and untrustworthy.
There was a piece on NPR just yesterday rating the top 4 candidates statements about the polls. The only one who was rated as true was.....Hillary, and yet the right and the left (Sanders supporters) continue with this narrative.

How can I see Clinton as a strong woman who will make a great president far superior to any of the others running while even the left can't get beyond the noise machine started back in the 1990's? How many times does she need to be vetted? How many times does Politico need to rate her as mostly true for the "liar" label to be lifted?

I feel like this whole process is an episode of the Twilight Zone. Cue Rod Serling to walk out smoking a cigarette and say "You're traveling through another dimension, a dimension not only of sight and sound but of mind."

"Fool me once shame on you, fool me twice shame on me".  So now all the blustering by Trump that erupted all the pent up fears, frustrations coupled with some racism and bigotry, was all a show to gain some recognition.  He will hence forth be more presidential, boring as he put it, but presidential.  Shame on those who believe that.

What a complete sham.

So Donald Trump is now saying that his extremist positions were just starting points of negotiation to bring in the base, and now he can start to "pivot" to bring in a broader base?

And how will he explain that to his "angry white working class base" who have been flocking to him precisely because they want him to export immigrants, keep out Muslims, and put women in "their place?"

They will abandon him immediately when they realize he has sold them out. And to everyone else, he will confirm that he is Lyin' Don.

Why anyone with a functioning brain vote for someone who is so in-your-face two-faced?

So, what this article is basically telling us, (in case we didn't already know) is that political campaigns are, for the most part, charades. Just a lot of posturing and pandering to lure this or that group into the fold, only to be recalibrated by the puppetmasters - themselves replaceable if their strategies aren't working - as the process evolves. And, of course, there's no accountability to the voting public whatsoever. You can promise the moon, and then renege once you get into office. At worst, you're approval rating might slip down a few points.

I said "for the most part" above, because there's one candidate this time around who does not fit into this model, who's as real as a politician can be, and that's Bernie Sanders. Not only has Bernie's message been consistent for the entire campaign, it's the same message he's been espousing for his entire political career. One can question whether his goals are achievable or not, but there's no question that he's genuinely dedicated to achieving them, and that he truly represents the interests of average citizens. The contrast between him and charlatans like Donald Trump, or Hillary Clinton, is as stark as it gets. He's our only hope for desperately needed meaningful change right now, and his loss in the campaign would be a true loss for the nation. If only more people could see it.

Really! The essence of American politics has become artfully packaging the types of mediocre people who gain power through government into something more and better than they actually are. They packaged Obama into some modern day Moses and still won't admit how much his "change" has failed us. The packaged Hillary Clinton into some adorable grandmother who purports to care about middle class families, when we know she is a hyper-ambitious nihilist who has corruptly chased after every penny of personal benefit she could get her hands on and would say anything to become President. Packaging Bernie Sanders as a principled man of ideas when everyone knows that he is just a traditional tax-the-rich socialist.

The sad part of all of this is that our electorate believes in these "fad diet" bromides, and expects these weak and flawed people to lead us. As a nation, we need to look in the mirror, admit that we, ourselves, are what is making America weak and impoverished, and stop looking to the magic of big government to save us.

As evidenced by Trump's rally last night in Pennsylvania and series of cable news interviews, Mr. Manafort would be well served to do HIS job. He is not a Trump tamer, with a whip and a chair. Mr. Trump made it abundantly clear yesterday and every day of his campaign that nobody "speaks" for him and not even his wife can order him to "tone it down."

Manafort had better concentrate on the looming chaos on the convention floor and steering Trump delegates where they need to go, and leave being Donald Trump to Donald Trump, or he will find himself out of a job.
